title: Gemini Man review: An oddly flat high-concept sci-fi action thriller
text:
Pros

No shock here, but Will Smith is a very charming, likeable screen presence who can do action sequences, one-liners and sciencey dialogue in his sleep. The challenge for him here is delivering two roles, one of which is significantly younger – think 51 vs 23 years of age – using the latest CGI dots-on-your-face-and-the-tech-guys-will-sort-it-later VFX. The resulting Fresh Prince-era Will Smith is a mixed bag, with the overall look a moderate success but certain specific details failing to deliver. There’s a slight upper lip blurring you might remember from Henry Cavill’s infamous moustache removal blooper during the Justice League reshoots, and that’s not a good look.

The performances are pretty good all round, with Benedict Wong’s cigar-chomping pilot pal Baron probably the stand-out – there’s a brief moment involving a toucan that’s delightful – and Mary Elizabeth Winstead’s Danny does a decent job as a fellow assassin on the run and Smith’s kinda-sorta love interest (though the age gap does feel a little off). Clive Owen has no problems as the villain as ever, and everyone is more or less, well, fine. Damning them with faint praise? Well, maybe a bit.

Certain action sequences are good fun, notably a motorbike fight between the Wills and some Budapest back and forth in some catacombs. When your director is Ang Lee and your producer is Jerry Bruckheimer, you’d expect quality in the spectacle department. If you enjoy explosions, gun play and fistfights in a natty new framerate, the film is also screening in high frame rate IMAX 3D+ in certain cinemas.

Cons

The script was written in the ‘90s and it feels like it. This comes over like a Face/Off knock-off, an oddly flat and pedestrian high-concept sci-fi action thriller that isn’t quite funny enough, dramatic or spectacular. Considering the talent involved, it’s a reverse miracle that it’s turned out this… bleh. The script has been kicking around for so long that directors including Tony Scott, Curtis Hanson and Joe Carnahan were all attached at some point, as were stars Harrison Ford, Mel Gibson, Clint Eastwood, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Sylvester Stallone and Sean Connery. Twenty years in development hell is a long time, and with the film finally out, it’s hard to work out why they saw it through. This is a film where I felt so disconnected from what was going on, I found myself counting the number of times Will Smith hugs someone. The final tally? Seven. Now you know.

There’s a sense that the cart was leading the horse, technology-wise. The “youthification” of Will Smith is impressive – we’ll see similar work done on Al Pacino, Joe Pesci and Robert De Niro for Scorsese’s upcoming The Irishman – but it’s not reason enough to make the movie, much like the high frame rate. It’s a gimmick, a neat trick, but ultimately it's not enough. More time spent on making sense of the story and injecting more life into the characters would have gone so much further than a few more days tweaking Will Smith’s forehead wrinkles.

Benedict Wong’s Baron can summon up a plane, a runway, whatever you need to fly across the planet as and when you need it, and honestly it’s a headscratching plothole that is almost dumbfounding. So… we’re going to go to all this trouble explaining how cloning can happen but we’re going to dismiss lots of other basic stuff with a wave of a hand?

Oh, and if you’re not a fan of product placement, definitely steer clear of this film, because there are some clanging “WOULD YOU LIKE A BEER?” moments.

Three word review: Flat, flimsy, tired.
